intro: Coprosma fauriei var. typica, commonly known as the New Zealand gloryflower, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its dense, evergreen foliage and clusters of small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 5 meters. Its leaves are glossy and dark green, often with a slight waxy coating, while the flowers are usually white or pale yellow. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in a variety of soil conditions.
